repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Local Governance Support
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The Bangladesh Local governance Support
            Project aims to support local governments in providing
            services that meet community priorities, using a predictable
            and transparent fiscal transfer system. The reallocation is
            necessary to for the reasons noted below: (1) there is an
            overall reduction in credit amount due to transfer of funds
            for the Emergency Cyclone Recovery and Restoration Project.
            This has led to a shortfall in financing the final tranche
            of expanded block grants and other components; (2) it was
            jointly decided between International Development
            Association (IDA) and the Government (and recorded in
            mission aide-memoires as well as management letters) that
            component five social protection pilot (US$2.1M) will be
            canceled because of substantial institutional hurdles faced
            with its implementation, and the credit proceeds will be
            reallocated to component one fiscal transfers; and (3) the
            performance grants under component one, which were to be
            rolled out across the country has not taken place because
            the planned arrangements for designing and implementing
            performance grants required more time than anticipated.
            Hence it was jointly agreed between IDA and the Government
            that the funds will be reallocated for expanded block
            grants. Further, it was also agreed that performance grants
            will be rolled out under the Second Local Governance Support Project.

6925630.trustfund:
TF093290-RAPID POLITICAL ECONOMY
            ASSESSMENT OF THE IMPACT OF RECENT NATIONAL EVE

abstracts.cdata!:
The Bangladesh Local governance Support
            Project aims to support local governments in providing
            services that meet community priorities, using a predictable
            and transparent fiscal transfer system. There are five
            project components. Component 1, funds fiscal transfers to
            eligible local governments for basic local service delivery
            and provides incentives for good governance and service
            delivery performance. Component 2 supports direct
            mobilization of communities to prioritize development needs,
            and community and government monitoring systems. Component 3
            supports core local government capacity development in
            implementing the block grant. Component 4 supports the
            Government in conducting regular, outcomes-based evaluations
            of the project in the context of the evolution of the local
            governance system. Component 5 supports a social protection
            pilot which will test the use of conditional transfers for
            national functions that can be devolved to local governments.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Local Governance Support
            Project : environmental and social management framework

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental and social management
            framework addresses potential environmental and social
            safeguard issues arising in the use of fiscal transfers to
            union Parishads in the Bangladesh Local Governance Support
            Project for Community Infrastructure Works (CIWs). To avoid
            any potential adverse impact all prospective CIWs will be
            screened, and to decrease potential negative adaptations
            will be made in design, location, or execution; cumulative
            impacts will be prevented or mitigated, positive impacts
            will be enhanced, and added stress on environmentally
            sensitive areas will be avoided. The project will exclude
            CIWs which may cause the following environmental impacts:
            works that close gaps or culverts in existing roads, which
            may affect water flow; tube-wells with arsenic contamination
            higher than the national standard or based below the 10-year
            flood level; water supply schemes with a high probability of
            bacterial contamination or characteristics which may make
            water unsuitable for drinking; health facilities without
            adequate hazardous waste management capacity; new or
            significant expansion of disposal facilities with negative
            health impacts to nearby water sources or population, or of
            disposal sites requiring involuntary public participation;
            building or repairing mechanized tube-wells for irrigation
            in deep aquifers leading to aquifer depletion or seasonal
            dams with adverse downstream effects; draining traditional
            wetlands for agricultural use; subprojects requiring
            pesticides; and activities supporting commercial logging in
            forested areas, or using unsustainable, harvested timber or
            fuelwood, or involving significant conversion or degradation
            of critical natural habitats. Also, CIWs that involve
            involuntary resettlement or affect indigenous peoples with
            long-term consequences will be ineligible for support.
